{{for|the former editorial director of Gizmodo|Brian Lam}} {{Infobox person | name = Brian Lamb | image = Brian_Lamb.jpg | caption = Lamb in January 2012 | birth_name = Brian Patrick Lamb | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1941|10|9}}<ref name=MaureenGroppe>{{cite news |title=Brian Lamb receives medal of freedom |author=Maureen Groppe |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4R3D-0C10-TX4T-41CT&csi=8217&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Gannett News Service |date=8 November 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> | birth_place = [[Lafayette, Indiana|Lafayette]], [[Indiana]], U.S. | occupation = [[Executive chairman]] of [[C-SPAN|C-SPAN's]] board of directors | networth = | spouse = Victoria Lamb (née Martin) (2005–present) | known for = Founder and former [[CEO]] of C-SPAN | children = | alma_mater = [[Purdue University]] | website = | signature = | footnotes = |module={{Infobox military person |allegiance={{Flagu|United States|1960}} |branch={{Naval|United States}} |unit={{USS|Thuban|AKA-19|6}} |embed=yes}} }}
'''Brian Patrick Lamb''' ({{IPAc-en|l|æ|m}}; born October 9, 1941)<ref name=PlayStr>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/051031/31lamb.htm |title=Playing It Straight |author=Peter Meredith |date=31 October 2005 |publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |accessdate=16 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222150817/http://www.usnews.com/usnews/news/articles/051031/31lamb.htm |archivedate=22 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> is an [[United States|American]] [[journalist]] and the founder, executive chairman, and now retired CEO of [[C-SPAN]]; an American [[Cable channel|cable network]] which provides coverage of the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] and [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] as well as other public affairs events. Prior to launching C-SPAN in 1979, Lamb held various communications roles including [[White House]] [[Telecommunications policy of the United States|telecommunications policy]] staffer and Washington bureau chief for ''Cablevision'' magazine. He also served as a commissioned officer in the [[United States Navy]] for four years. Lamb has conducted thousands of interviews in his lifetime, including those on C-SPAN's ''[[Booknotes]]'' and ''[[Q&A (U.S. talk show)|Q&A]]'', and is known for his unique interview style, focusing on short, direct questions. Over the course of his career Lamb has received numerous honors and awards including the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] and the [[National Humanities Medal]].
==Early life and education== Lamb was born in [[Lafayette, Indiana]]<ref name=Aamidor>{{cite news |title= Q&A Brian Lamb Founder, CEO of C-SPAN |author= Abe Aamidor |url=http://www.indy.com/posts/q-a-brian-lamb-founder-ceo-of-c-span |newspaper= ''[[The Indianapolis Star]]''|page= I12|date= 25 May 2008}}</ref> and lived there until he was 22 years old. Growing up, he wanted to be an entertainer and spent time as a [[disc jockey]] and as a [[drummer]] in many local bands.<ref name=Freeman/><ref name=ChanChan>{{cite journal |date=March–April 2003|title= Changing the Channel|journal= National Endowment for the Humanities |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030401141916/http://www.neh.gov:80/news/humanities/2003-03/channel.html|access-date=April 1, 2003|volume= 24|issue= 2|pages= 14+|issn= 0018-7526}}</ref> Lamb showed an early interest in television and radio: he started his first radio job at a local station in Lafayette, [[WASK (AM)]], at the age of 17,<ref name=Cullen>{{cite news |title=Legend's Lafayette ties strong |author=Kevin Cullen |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=470F-9C20-01D1-S50G&csi=256482&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Journal and Courier (Lafayette, IN) |date=27 July 2002 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=Manip/> working as a disc jockey and selling advertisements.<ref name=MaureenGroppe/> His job at the radio station gave him the opportunity to interview musicians including [[Louis Armstrong]], [[Duke Ellington]], [[Nat King Cole]], [[Count Basie]], and [[The Kingston Trio]], while he was still in high school.<ref name=Freeman/><ref name=Manip/> In 1961, during his junior year at college, he coordinated a television program titled ''Dance Date'', similar to [[Dick Clark]]'s [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] series, ''[[American Bandstand]]''.<ref name=ChanChan/>
After graduation from [[Jefferson High School (Lafayette, Indiana)|Jefferson High School]], Lamb attended [[Purdue University]],<ref name=Cullen/> where he was a member of [[Phi Gamma Delta]]<ref name=FIJI>{{cite web |url=http://www.purduegreeks.com/famousAlumni.php here |title=Famous Alumni |work=purduegreeks.com |publisher=Purdue Interfraternity Council |accessdate=28 February 2012}}</ref> and graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] in Speech in 1963.<ref name=PlayStr/><ref name=States/>
==Military service== Following graduation from Purdue, Lamb was accepted into the [[United States Navy]] [[Officer Candidate School (U.S. Navy)|Officer Candidate School]]. Upon completion of his training, he served 18 months on the [[Amphibious cargo ship|attack cargo ship]] {{USS|Thuban|AKA-19|6}}, and then moved to the Pentagon where he served in the audio/visual office of the [[Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs]]. Lamb took up this role midway through the [[Vietnam War]] and, in addition to handling queries from radio and television networks,<ref name=Stewart>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN founder among Lone Sailor awardees |author=Joshua Stewart |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=534M-5K51-DYJJ-P1VF&csi=275831&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Navy Times |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> he attended press briefings with [[United States Secretary of Defense|Defense Secretary]] [[Robert McNamara]].<ref name=Barnhart/> In July 1967, following [[1967 Detroit riot|riots in Detroit]], Lamb was sent there and tasked with providing recordings of news conferences of [[Governor of Michigan|Governor]] [[George W. Romney]] of Michigan for the [[White House Situation Room]].<ref name=ChanChan/> He also served as a [[White House Military Office|White House social aide]] to [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], in which role he escorted [[Lady Bird Johnson]] down the aisle at the wedding of [[Chuck Robb]] and [[Lynda Bird Johnson Robb|Lynda Johnson]]. He later recalled, "For five years after I got out of the Navy and went back part of the time to Indiana, the only thing I was known to have ever done in my life was to escort Mrs. Johnson down the aisle."<ref name=ChanChan/> Lamb spent a total of four years in the U.S. Navy and was a [[Lieutenant (junior grade)|Lieutenant, junior grade]] at the time that he left.<ref name=Stewart/> He later said that his time in the U.S. Navy "was probably the most important thing [he has] ever done".<ref name=ChanChan/>
==Early career==
===Communications and journalism work=== In December 1967, following his Navy service, Lamb's interest in politics led him to interview for the role of personal aide to [[Richard Nixon]] during his campaign for the [[United States presidential election, 1968|1968 presidential election]], but instead he returned to Indiana . In August 1968, after working at a local television station in Lafayette, he spent ten weeks working for a group called United Citizens for [[Richard Nixon presidential campaign, 1968|Nixon-Agnew]].<ref name=Prato>{{cite news |title=The Man Behind C-SPAN |author=Lou Prato |url=http://ajr.org/article_printable.asp?id=1503 |work=American Journalism Review |date=September 1992 |accessdate=8 December 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603061946/http://www.ajr.org/article_printable.asp?id=1503# |archive-date=2013-06-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Following the campaign, he worked as a reporter for UPI Audio<ref name=Truman>{{cite web|url=http://www.trumanaward.org/web/LambBio.html |title=Mr. Brian Lamb's Bio |publisher=The Harry S. Truman Good Neighbor Award Foundation |accessdate=8 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120194119/http://www.trumanaward.org/web/LambBio.html |archivedate=20 January 2012 |df= }}</ref> and in 1969 became press secretary for Senator [[Peter H. Dominick]] (R-Colo.),<ref name=Tyree>{{cite news|title=OU honors C-SPAN founder with Gaylord Prize |author=James S. Tyree |url=http://normantranscript.com/headlines/x867535362/OU-honors-C-SPAN-founder-with-Gaylord-Prize |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130130020004/http://normantranscript.com/headlines/x867535362/OU-honors-C-SPAN-founder-with-Gaylord-Prize |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 January 2013 |work=The Norman Transcript |date=9 November 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011 }}</ref> before becoming an assistant for media and congressional relations to [[Clay T. Whitehead]], director of the White House [[Office of Telecommunications Policy]].<ref name=Truman /><ref name="Groppe2">{{cite news |title=C-SPAN founder's life is an open book |author=Maureen Groppe |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4SSF-S880-TWWW-R1F2&csi=252052&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=The Indianapolis Star |date=15 June 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
After the White House, Lamb returned to journalism as the editor of a biweekly newsletter entitled, ''The Media Report''.<ref name=Truman/><ref name=TargetedNews/> While editing ''The Media Report'', he also became the Washington bureau chief of trade magazine ''Cablevision''<ref name=Kirtley>{{cite news |title=Founding Father: How C-SPAN's Brian Lamb Changed Politics in America |author=Jane E. Kirtley |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=7X6Y-S3F0-YBD4-14R9&csi=312761&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Journalism and Mass Communications Quarterly |date=Winter 2008 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=TVNewsCheck/> for four years,<ref name=Prial/> covering telecommunications issues.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Top 100: Brian Lamb, C-SPAN Founder |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4K1X-VYD0-TX2H-V3C9&csi=11341&oc=00240&perma=true |work=Irish America |date=31 May 2005 |page=94 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> During this time, he developed his idea of creating a public affairs-oriented cable network.<ref name=Kemper>{{cite news |title=Brian Lamb: An Outsider Inside Washington |author=Bob Kemper |url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2009/05/brian-lamb-outsider-inside-washington |newspaper=Washington Examiner |date=9 May 2009 |accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref>
==C-SPAN== {{main article|C-SPAN}} In 1977, Lamb submitted to cable television executives a proposal for a nonprofit channel that would broadcast official proceedings of [[United States Congress|Congress]].<ref name=PurePol>{{cite news |title= Pure Politics|work= Scene|page= SC1|date= 17 June 1993 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=45xJMl18F20C&pg=PA289 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> He later said, "The risks weren't very significant. No one knew who I was. If I failed, so what?"<ref name=PlayStr/> The idea was approved in December 1977 and the [[C-SPAN|Cable Satellite Public Affairs Network]] was created as a private nonprofit business with a board of cable-operating company executives, funded by affiliate fees from cable companies.<ref name=Heath>{{cite news |title=Value Added: A 46-Year Career Built on Letting Viewers Make Up Their Own Minds |author=Thomas Heath |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/value-added-a-46-year-career-built-on-letting-viewers-make-up-their-own-minds/2011/09/15/gIQA3IaEdK_story_1.html |work=Washington Post |date=18 September 2011 |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref><ref name=Bedard/> At its launch the network had a staff of four employees, including Lamb, and an annual budget of [[United States dollar|US$]]450,000. The first broadcast occurred on March 19, 1979, with live coverage of the first televised [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] floor debate.<ref name=Freeman>{{cite news |title=Good interviews are Brian Lamb's style |author=Don Freeman |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4PB2-NJK0-TWDC-M40G&csi=11811&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=The San Diego Union-Tribune |date=5 February 1989 |pages= TV week 6 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=CKind>{{cite news |title= A C-SPAN kind of man: Brian Lamb is a mirror of his creation |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2001-03-05/features/0103050061_1_c-span-lamb-noisemakers |pages= 1E |publisher= ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]''|date= 5 March 2001 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
By 2010, C-SPAN reached over 100 million households,<ref name=Bedard>{{cite news |title=Brian Lamb: C-SPAN Now Reaches 100 Million Homes |author=Paul Bedard |url=https://www.usnews.com/news/blogs/washington-whispers/2010/06/22/brian-lamb-c-span-now-reaches-100-million-homes |newspaper=usnews.com |date=22 June 2010 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> and the network employed 275 individuals in [[Washington D.C.]] and at its archives in [[West Lafayette, Indiana|West Lafayette]].<ref name=Heath/> Its coverage includes a variety of public affairs programming, including presidential press conferences and Senate hearings, in addition to its gavel-to-gavel coverage of the House and Senate.<ref name=JournalCourier/> {{As of|2011}}, C-SPAN consists of three networks: C-SPAN, C-SPAN2 and C-SPAN3 plus a radio station, with more than 170,000 hours of C-SPAN footage available online via the [[C-SPAN Video Library]].<ref name=Aamidor/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/about |title=Our Mission |work=c-spanvideo.org |publisher=C-SPAN |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref> Lamb is the former CEO and president of C-SPAN, and now serves as executive chairman of its board of directors.<ref name=Freeman/><ref name="C-Span Founder to Step Down"/><ref name=TheAssociatedPress>{{cite news |title=Don't worry, Brian Lamb fans. C-SPAN founder still aboard despite net's new presidents |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4MH1-3PM0-TW8Y-S20S&csi=304478&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=The Associated Press |date=4 December 2006 |accessdate=14 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=AllThings>{{Cite episode |title=C-SPAN network celebrates its 20th year on the air quietly |episodelink= |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1047235 |series=All Things Considered |credits=Anchor: Linda Wertheimer, Reporter: Mary Ann Akers |network=National Public Radio (NPR) |airdate=19 March 1999 |accessdate=15 February 2012 }}</ref> He has described the network as "in every single way, the antithesis of commercial television".<ref name=ChanChan/>
In March 2012, Lamb announced his plan to step down as CEO, handing control over to Rob Kennedy and Susan Swain.<ref name="C-Span Founder to Step Down">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/19/business/media/c-span-founder-brian-lamb-to-step-down-as-ceo.html?_r=0|title=C-Span Founder to Step Down as Chief Executive|work=NYTimes|date=March 18, 2012|accessdate=Mar 11, 2013|first=Brian|last=Stelter}}</ref>
===Hosting and interview style=== On C-SPAN, Lamb hosted ''[[Washington Journal]]'', ''[[Booknotes]]'', and continues to host ''[[Q&A (U.S. talk show)|Q&A]]'',<ref name="C-Span Founder to Step Down"/> and through these programs has become known for his distinctive interview style.<ref name=Myers>{{cite news |title=D.C. in a plain brown wrapper; When he started C-SPAN 25 years ago, Brian Lamb created 24-hour catnip for policy wonks, bookworms and the civic-minded |author=Donald P. Myers |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4BXV-K5D0-TWCV-423R&csi=306889&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Newsday (New York) |date=15 March 2004 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> According to him, he learned the basics of broadcasting and interviewing from his high school broadcasting teacher, Bill Fraser,<ref name=Freeman/><ref name=Manip/> who taught him to "stay out of the way" while he conducted interviews.<ref name=Freeman/>
Lamb does not discuss his own political views.<ref name=Gillespie>{{cite web |url=http://reason.com/archives/2010/11/16/the-democratizer |title=The Democratizer |author=Nick Gillespie |date=December 2010 |work=Reason.com |publisher=Reason Magazine |accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref>
According to ''The Advocate'', his style of interviewing is "Spartan",<ref name=Advocate/> and he has stated: "Too many interviewers intrude too much. … They try to make us think they're smarter than the person they're interviewing. Well, I assume I'm not smarter and if I am smarter I don't want the audience to find out."<ref name=Freeman/>
If a guest uses a term of art such as "cloture" he will ask them to define it for the audience, and invariably will ask the guest where they went to school, his or her children's names, and occupations.
===''Booknotes''===
In his 35 years at C-SPAN, Lamb has conducted thousands of interviews,<ref name=Aamidor/> including 801 editions of ''[[Booknotes]]'', a weekly program he hosted focusing on nonfiction books.<ref name=PlayStr/><ref name=TargetedNews/><ref name=Slices>{{cite news |title=Slices of History; Excerpts from author interviews on C-SPAN's 'Booknotes' are compiled by host; Brian Lamb |author=Susan L. Rife |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=44MN-N9G0-00D6-K1M4&csi=155265&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Sarasota Herald-Tribune (Florida) |date=9 December 2001 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> His first ''Booknotes'' interview was broadcast on April 2, 1989,<ref name=TheAssociatedPress/> and the final program aired on December 4, 2004.<ref name=Prial>{{cite news |title=After Many Million Pages, 'Booknotes' Ends Its Run |author=Frank J. Prial |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/04/arts/television/04lamb.html?pagewanted=print&position= |newspaper=The New York Times |date=4 December 2004 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> Over the course of the program, Lamb's interviewees included notable authors, politicians, and world leaders including [[George H. W. Bush]], [[George W. Bush]], [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Bill Clinton]], [[Mikhail Gorbachev]], [[Richard Nixon]], [[Colin Powell]], and [[Margaret Thatcher]].<ref name=TheAssociatedPress/><ref name=Basbanes>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN founder finds a literary niche or authors on 'Bookends' |author=Nicholas A. Basbanes |authorlink=Nicholas A. Basbanes|url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SR9-W310-00D5-Y2DY&csi=155406&oc=00240&perma=true |work=Sunday Telegram (Massachusetts) |date=27 July 1997 |page=C5 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
The program's format was described in its tagline, "One author, one book, one hour",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.booknotes.org/about/ |title=About Booknotes |accessdate=15 November 2008 |publisher=[[C-SPAN]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090131193918/http://www.booknotes.org/about/ |archivedate=31 January 2009 |df= }}</ref> and Lamb has stated that he spent an average of 20 hours reading and preparing for each interview,<ref name=PlayStr/> though by some counts he spoke for less than five minutes over the course of each program.<ref name=BookStap>{{cite news |title='Booknotes' a C-SPAN staple Authors, ideas attract the attention when Brian Lamb asks basic questions |author=Ed Will |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=3SVB-D880-000T-G0PC&csi=144565&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=The Denver Post |page=F05 |date=1 June 1998 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
Lamb has also published five books based on ''Booknotes'' interviews, each a collection of essays written from transcripts of his interviews with authors.<ref name=BookStap/><ref name=Mysak>{{cite news |title=Lincoln’s Ego, Wife, Prose Style Explored in Bicentennial Books |author=Joe Mysak |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aAa9Y_q9TYTg&refer=muse |work=Bloomberg.com |date=4 February 2009 |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref> The books focus on writing, biographies of figures from American history, American history stories, "American character" and the life of [[Abraham Lincoln]], respectively.<ref name=Prial/><ref name=Mysak/><ref name=Dempsey>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN Creator/Show Host Chronicles Events of America; Brian Lamb's love for books has resulted in four of his own |author=Laura Dempsey |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=44GM-HD90-0027-X0YV&csi=144574&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Dayton Daily News |date=18 November 2001 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref>
After ''Booknotes'' ended, Lamb began hosting a new program titled ''Q&A'', featuring interviews with notable figures from politics, technology, education, and media, as well as authors.<ref name=TVNewsCheck/><ref name=TheAssociatedPress/><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.c-span.org/series/?qa|title= About Q&A|accessdate=27 November 2014 |publisher= [[C-SPAN]]}}</ref> He also continued to host ''Washington Journal'', C-SPAN's morning call-in program, until 2008.<ref name=TheAssociatedPress/><ref name=NewsCheck/>
In 2011, Lamb donated his collection of books from the ''Booknotes'' series, many containing his personal marginalia, to the rare books collection of [[George Mason University]] to create an academic archive.<ref name=Kelly>{{cite news |title=In Brian Lamb's 'Booknotes' marginalia, a record of our time's serious thoughts |author=John Kelly |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/in-brian-lambs-booknotes-marginalia-a-record-of-our-times-serious-thoughts/2011/09/21/gIQA8EwzlK_story.html |work=The Washington Post |date=21 September 2011 |accessdate=8 December 2011}}</ref>
===Issues=== As CEO of C-SPAN, Lamb was involved in issues related to ensuring public access to the proceedings of the federal government and also to increasing media access to legislative and judicial proceedings. Lamb opposed the "[[must-carry]]" provisions of the [[Cable Television Protection and Competition Act]] of 1992, which he later stated had led to 10 million Americans losing or experiencing reduced access to C-SPAN.<ref name=Lardner>{{cite news |title=The Anti-Network |author=James Lardner |url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/1994/03/14/1994_03_14_049_TNY_CARDS_000364044 |newspaper=The New Yorker |date=14 March 1994 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Lamb: Digital Rule Could Bump Cable Net in Millions of Homes Cable |author=Brooks Boliek |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/services/motion-pictures/4928575-1.html |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=29 May 1998 |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref> In 1998, he wrote to the [[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|House Committee on Energy and Commerce]] and [[United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation|Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation]], arguing against digital must-carry legislation.<ref name=NewsCheck>{{cite web |url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/2010/04/20/41591/cspan-the-other-washington-monument |title=C-SPAN: The Other Washington Monument |date=20 April 2010 |work=TVNewsCheck.com |accessdate=12 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Stern>{{cite news |title=C-Span chief pans digital must-carry |author=Christopher Stern |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117471381?refCatId=18 |newspaper=Daily Variety |date=1 June 1998 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=Stern/> During the [[impeachment of President Clinton]], Lamb wrote to then-Senate Majority Leader [[Trent Lott]], urging the Senate to "keep this process open to the public" and formally requesting permission for televised coverage of the Senate's deliberations.<ref name=Warren>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN's Beltway Buddha Wisely Pushes for TV Coverage |author=James Warren |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/37922117.html?dids=37922117:37922117&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+10%2C+1999&author=James+Warren.&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=C-SPAN'S+BELTWAY+BUDDHA+WISELY+PUSHES+FOR+TV+COVERAGE&pqatl=google |newspaper=Chicago Tribune |date=10 January 1999 |accessdate=9 November 2011}}</ref> In addition, he has written to House Speakers of both parties in 1994, 2006 and 2010, requesting that independent media cameras be added to the House floor to allow a more complete view of debates.<ref>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN asks GOP leader John Boehner for more camera access |author=Catalina Camia |url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2010/11/c-span-john-boehner-house-cameras-/1 |work=USA Today |date=15 November 2010 |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN to Incoming House Speaker John Boehner: Let Us Use Our Own Cameras to Cover Congress |author=Alex Weprin |url=http://www.mediabistro.com/tvnewser/c-span-to-incoming-house-speaker-john-boehner-let-us-use-our-own-cameras-to-cover-congress_b39751 |work=TVNewser |publisher=Mediabistro |date=15 November 2010 |accessdate=3 January 2012}}</ref> Lamb has also written to chief justices Rehnquist and Roberts requesting the televising of [[Oral argument in the United States|oral arguments]] before the [[Supreme Court of the United States]]<ref>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN asks court to allow TV coverage |newspaper=The Victoria Advocate |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=861&dat=20001125&id=NMlaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gXgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6754,6777917 |date=25 November 2000 |page=7A |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Ardor in the Court |author=Michael McGough |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1129&dat=20051114&id=bPBRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=53ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=6830,3020997 |newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |date=14 November 2005 |page=B7 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> and other federal courts.<ref name="Groppe2" /><ref name=Weyrich>{{cite news |title=Nice Guys Don't Always Finish Last |author=Paul M. Weyrich |url=http://www.humanevents.com/article.php?id=3441 |newspaper=Human Events Online |date=30 March 2004 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref>
==Bibliography== In addition to his five books based on ''Booknotes'' interviews, Lamb has written a book with [[Richard Norton Smith]] about the gravesites of American presidents, ''Who's Buried in Grant's Tomb? A Tour of Presidential Gravesites'',<ref>{{cite news |title=CNN Saturday Morning News: The Novak Zone |author=Robert Novak |work=CNN |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0401/31/smn.09.html |date=31 January 2004 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref> and a companion book to a series of C-SPAN interviews with Supreme Court justices, ''The Supreme Court: A C-SPAN Book, Featuring the Justices in their Own Words''.
A complete list of his published works: *''C-SPAN: America's Town Hall'' (1988) Brian Lamb and C-SPAN staff, Acropolis Books {{ISBN|0-87491-889-8}} *''Booknotes: America's Finest Authors on Reading, Writing, and the Power of Ideas'' (1998) Brian Lamb, Times Books {{ISBN|978-0-8129-3029-0}} *''Booknotes Life Stories: Notable Biographers on the People Who Shaped America'' (2000) Brian Lamb, Times Books {{ISBN|978-0-8129-3339-0}} *''Booknotes: Stories from American History'' (2002) Brian Lamb, [[PublicAffairs]] {{ISBN|978-0-14-200249-0}} *''Who's Buried in Grant's Tomb? A Tour of Presidential Gravesites'' (2003) Brian Lamb and Richard Norton Smith [[Johns Hopkins University Press]] {{ISBN|978-1-58648-178-0}} *''Booknotes: On American Character'' (2005) Brian Lamb [[PublicAffairs]] {{ISBN|978-1-58648-342-5}} *''Abraham Lincoln: Great American Historians on Our Sixteenth President'' (2008) Brian Lamb and Susan Swain, [[PublicAffairs]], [[New York City]] {{ISBN|978-1-58648-676-1}} *''The Supreme Court: A C-SPAN Book, Featuring the Justices in their Own Words'' (2010) Brian Lamb and Susan Swain, [[PublicAffairs]] {{ISBN|1-58648-835-X}}
==Awards and recognition== Lamb has received numerous honors and awards for his work at C-SPAN. He was the recipient of the [[National Press Club (USA)|National Press Club]]'s Fourth Estate Award in 2002.<ref name="U.S.Newswire">{{cite news |title=National Press Club to Honor Brian Lamb with Fourth Estate Award |newspaper=U.S. Newswire |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/api/version1/sr?sr=%22National+Press+Club+to+Honor+Brian+Lamb+with+Fourth+Estate+Award%22&csi=8399&oc=00240&shr=t&scl=t&hac=f&hct=f&nonLatin1Chars=true |date=24 April 2002 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> The following year, he was awarded the [[National Humanities Medal]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neh.gov/news/report2002/medals.html|title=National Humanities Medal|accessdate=15 November 2008 |work=2002 Annual Report|publisher=[[National Endowment for the Humanities]] Official site}}</ref><ref name="Smith">{{cite news |title=Adapting their skills to life |author=Erin Smith |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=48K7-K040-01D1-S3TR&csi=256482&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Journal and Courier (Lafayette, IN) |date=5 May 2003 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> the Harry S. Truman Good Neighbor Award,<ref name="Barnhart">{{cite news |title=Win like a lamb; C-SPAN remains a reliable source thanks to founder's fair approach |author=Aaron Barnhart |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=48H7-J1B0-010F-S1NX&csi=145214&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Kansas City Star |date=3 May 2003 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> and The Media Institute's Freedom of Speech Award.<ref name="States" />
In November 2007, Lamb received the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] for his work at C-SPAN.<ref name=JournalCourier>{{cite news |title=Lamb opened government with C-SPAN |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4R2X-FHC0-TWWX-S08V&csi=256482&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=Journal and Courier |date=3 November 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Citations Recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom|url= https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/11/20071105-7.html|publisher=The White House: Official Site|date= 5 November 2007|accessdate=13 November 2008}}</ref> The medal is the highest civilian award in the United States, and the White House announcement stated that Lamb had received the award for his "dedication to a transparent political system and to the free flow of ideas".<ref>{{cite news |title=Brian Lamb receives medal of freedom |author=Maureen Groppe |agency=Gannett News Service |date=8 November 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Citations Recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom|url=https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/11/20071105-7.html|website=georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov|publisher=White House official website|accessdate=29 April 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name=WashingtonTimes>{{cite news |title=An honorable recipient |newspaper=The Washington Times |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4R56-CKD0-TWCW-402X&csi=8176&oc=00240&perma=true |date=17 November 2007 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> In September 2011, Lamb received The Lone Sailor award from the [[United States Navy Memorial|U.S. Navy Memorial]], recognizing individuals who begin their careers in the Navy, but go on to have "exceptional civilian careers".<ref name=Stewart/>
In addition, he has received a number of communications-related awards, including the Manship Prize for Exemplary Use of Media and Technology from [[Louisiana State University]]'s Manship School of Mass Communication,<ref name=Advocate>{{cite news |title=''Booknotes'' was benefit for books |newspaper=The Advocate |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4F0X-H310-TWJV-823K&csi=144563&oc=00240&perma=true |date=11 December 2004 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> and the [[Al Neuharth]] Award for Excellence in the Media.<ref name=TargetedNews>{{cite news |title=C-SPAN Founder, Chairman And CEO Brian Lamb To Receive Al Neuharth Award At USD On Oct. 6 |url=http://www.usd.edu/press/news/news.cfm?nid=2238 |publisher=University of San Diego |agency=Targeted News Service |date=23 August 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> In 2011, he was awarded the Gaylord Prize for Excellence in Journalism sponsored by the [[Gaylord College of Journalism and Mass Communication]] at the [[University of Oklahoma]],<ref name=Tyree>{{cite news|title=OU honors C-SPAN founder with Gaylord Prize |author=James S. Tyree |url=http://normantranscript.com/headlines/x867535362/OU-honors-C-SPAN-founder-with-Gaylord-Prize |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130130020004/http://normantranscript.com/headlines/x867535362/OU-honors-C-SPAN-founder-with-Gaylord-Prize |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 January 2013 |work=The Norman Transcript |date=9 November 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011 }}</ref><ref name=Eggerton>{{cite news |title=Lamb Wins Gaylord Prize |author=John Eggerton |url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/473739-Lamb_Wins_Gaylord_Prize.php |newspaper=Broadcasting & Cable |date=13 September 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref> and was named as one of [[Library of American Broadcasting]]'s 2011 "Giants of Broadcasting".<ref name=TVNewsCheck>{{cite news|title=Williams, Amanpour, Lamb, Join LAB Giants |url=http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/2011/09/11/53882/williams-amanpour-lamb-join-lab-giants/format/print |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130205024919/http://www.tvnewscheck.com/article/2011/09/11/53882/williams-amanpour-lamb-join-lab-giants/format/print |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 February 2013 |newspaper=TVNewsCheck |date=11 September 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011 }}</ref>
Lamb has received numerous honorary doctorates, including one from his alma mater, [[Purdue University]].<ref name=States>{{cite news |title=Purdue Names School of Communication for C-SPAN Founder |url=http://www.purdue.edu/newsroom/general/2011/110408CordovaCommunicatio.html |agency=States News Service |date=8 April 2011 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref><ref name=StatesNews>{{cite news |title=Plumeri to Class of 2011: Take Risks and Anything is Possible |newspaper=States News Service |url=http://www.wm.edu/news/stories/2011/plumeri-to-class-of-2011-take-risks-and-anything-is-possible-123.php |date=16 May 2011 |accessdate=16 February 2012}}</ref> Purdue also awarded him its Distinguished Alumni Award in 1987 and in 2011 its communications department was renamed as the Brian Lamb School of Communication.<ref name=States/><ref name=AssociatedPress>{{cite news |title=Purdue naming new communications school after C-SPAN founder Brian Lamb, a Purdue alumnus |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/sns-ap-in--purdue-c-spanfounder,0,3155394 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130119082220/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/sns-ap-in--purdue-c-spanfounder,0,3155394 |archive-date=19 January 2013 |agency=Associated Press |date=4 September 2011 |accessdate=9 November 2011 |deadurl=yes}} </ref> In 2015, Lamb was awarded an honorary doctorate from [[Gettysburg College]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Varner|first1=Casey|title=Class of 2015: Preparing for the 180th Commencement|url=http://www.gettysburg.edu/news_events/press_release_detail.dot?id=feba5e8f-68ac-4300-8f07-e658214d5371|publisher=Gettysburg College|accessdate=5 June 2015}}</ref>
==Personal life== Lamb has spent most of his life in [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref name=Prial/> and currently lives with his wife, Victoria, in [[Arlington County, Virginia|Arlington, Virginia]].<ref name=TargetedNews/> He married Victoria Martin in September 2005.<ref name=Kemper/> The couple met in grade school at [[Cathedral of Saint Mary of the Immaculate Conception in Indiana|St. Mary's Cathedral]] and had dated in Washington, D.C. in the 1970s, later restarting their relationship in 1998.<ref name=Manip>{{cite news |title= CSPAN's Lamb: Americans Feel Manipulated |author=[[Ronald Kessler]] |url=http://www.newsmax.com/RonaldKessler/Brian-Lamb/2008/01/30/id/322798 |publisher= [[Newsmax Media]]|date= 30 January 2008 |accessdate=14 November 2011}}</ref><ref name=Myers/><ref>{{cite web |url= https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2007/11/images/20071105-7_d-0223-3-515h.html|title= Citations Recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom|accessdate=14 November 2008 |work= Picture caption|publisher= The White House: Official Site|date= 5 November 2007}}</ref> Lamb has never been a member of a political party, though he did work for the Republican [[Richard Nixon|Nixon]]-[[Spiro Agnew|Agnew]] campaign in 1968.<ref name=Prial/> He is not registered as a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] or [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]]. He has voted for candidates across the political spectrum during presidential elections.<ref name=Manip/><ref name=Leibovich>{{cite news |title=Brian Lamb's Flock; The Unassuming C-SPAN Founder and Host Has a Faithful Audience |author=Mark Leibovich |url=http://w3.nexis.com/new/docview/getDocForCuiReq?lni=4683-XDB0-010F-91P4&csi=8075&oc=00240&perma=true |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=11 July 2002 |accessdate=15 February 2012}}</ref> In an interview Lamb stated he has "been listening to both sides so long that I don't know what I think anymore."<ref name=PurePol/> The late writer [[Christopher Hitchens]] dedicated his 2005 biography of [[Thomas Jefferson]] to Lamb; on the title page appear the words, "For Brian Lamb... a fine democrat as well as a good republican, who has striven for an educated electorate".

{{Infobox ancient site | name = Catacomb of San Pancrazio | native_name = Catacomba di San Pancrazio | alternate_name = | image = San Pancrazio - ingresso 1534.JPG | alt = The entrance to the church and catacomb of San Pancrazio | caption = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_size = | relief = | coordinates = {{coord|41.885|N|12.454|E|display=inline,title}} | location = Rome, Italy | region = | type = [[Catacomb]] | part_of = | length = | width = | area = | diameter = | circumference = | volume = | height = | builder = | material = | built = | abandoned = | epochs = [[Early Christian art and architecture|Early Christian]] | cultures = | dependency_of = | occupants = | event = | excavations = | archaeologists = | condition = | ownership = | management = [[Pontifical Commission of Sacred Archaeology]] | public_access = Yes | designation1 = | other_designation = | website = www.sanpancrazio.org | notes = }} The '''Catacomb of San Pancrazio''' (also called '''of Ottavilla''') is a [[Catacombs of Rome|catacomb of Rome]] ([[Italy]]), located in the [[Via Aurelia]], within the modern ''Quartiere'' Gianicolense.
==The martyrs== The catacomb is especially known to have Pancras from Phrygia, a famous martyr, buried within its walls. Pancras was entrusted to his uncle Dionysus at age 8,after his parents died, and they both came to Rome. Saint Pancras converted to Christianity while in Rome and at the age of 14, he was beheaded in May 304 AD (around 303 AD Christians were being persecuted for their faith) when he refused to sacrifice to the gods. Before Diocletian, emperor at the time, was impressed with how young Pancras was and how he had the courage to refuse sacrificing to the Gods, so he offered Pancras money and power to leave the Christian faith, but Pancras still refused so he was beheaded and thrown to the side.
His body was abandoned on the Via Aurelia and was picked up by a Christian matrona, Ottavilla, who buried him. Ottavilla found the body and the head on May 12 304 AD, she picked them up, wrapped Pancras in precious linen and buried him specifically in the Catacombs that stood there. His head was eventually placed in a precious manner in the Basilica, the body lays in an urn and the site still reads "Hic decollatus fuit Sanctus Pancratius" (Here San Pancrazio was taken off) ". His body now rests among other martyrs buried in the Catacombs.
The ancient sources, particularly the Medieval itineraries for pilgrims, mention other martyrs buried within the catacomb: Artemy, Paulinus, Sophia and her three daughters Faith, Hope and Charity. The resting place of the last four martyrs can probably be identified with the so-called cubicle of St. Sophia.
The cult of St. Pancras highly spread during the Middle Ages, so much so that the catacomb bearing his name was one of the few in Rome that could always be visited by the pilgrims. The once di Calepodio cemetery, where Pancras was buried, changed its name to the Catacombs of San Pancrazio. The first notice about the martyrdom of Pancras comes from the Martyrologium Hieronymianum, that sets the date of the death at 12 May.
==History== Between the end of the 4th century and the beginning of the 5th, Pope Symmachus built a basilica above the catacomb consecrated to the martyr and a thermal edifice. In 594 Gregory the Great provided the basilica with a cloister. In 625 Pope Honorius I rebuilt the basilica after a Greek-Gothic war, with three naves. Pope Honorius' rebuilding is the basilica that still exists today.
As mentioned above, San Pancrazio is one of the few catacombs in Rome whose track has not been completely lost during the centuries, even if it has often been confused with other catacombs rising along the Via Aurelia. Antonio Bosio thoroughly studied the cemetery, but he confused it with the cemetery of Calepodius; the two catacombs were distinguished by Giovanni Battista de Rossi in the 19th century.
Excavations carried out at the beginning of the 1930s under the floor of the Basilica of San Pancrazio led to the discovery of a Roman street that cut in two, diagonally to the church; they also brought to light some mausolea and ground graves, both inside the basilica and in its square, such demonstrating that the hypogeous cemetery also included an extended funerary area on the topsoil.
==Topography and description==
The Catacomb of San Pancrazio is not in the most perfect condition: the tunnels are mostly destroyed and therefore the visit to see the Catacomb is very short.
The hypogeous cemerety can be divided into three main regions:
*The first region is placed below the left transept of the basilica and behind the apse and its access is still the former entrance, within the left nave. This region was explored in the first half of the 20th century by Father Fusciardi.
*In the right nave, a trapdoor gives access to the second region, placed below the square in front of the basilica. In this region it is possible to visit:
The cubicle of Botrys, from the name of the decedent buried in it. The peculiarity of this grave is that, on his headstone, Botrys declares himself as a christianós, an unusual expression in the Christian graveyards.
The cubicle of Saint Felix, dating back to the end of the 3rd and the beginning of the 4th century, decorated with a linear red style and elements referring to the sea (ships and fishes).
The cubicle of Saint Sophia, housing a white-plastered arcosolium with four graves, that are believed to be the martyr Sophia and her three daughters'.
*Finally, the third region is placed below the cloister. Within the third region there are widespread Constantinian Christograms, which lead the researchers to believe that this part of the hypogeous cemetery has been built in the 4th century.

Ickes]] | founding_location = United States | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[For-profit corporation]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = | headquarters = | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | region = | services = | products = | methods = [[Microtargeting]] | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|http://www.catalist.us}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} '''Catalist''' is a for-profit corporation based in Washington, D.C., that operates a [[voter database]].<ref name=atlantic>{{cite news|last1=Ambinder|first1=Marc|title=Exclusive: How Democrats Won The Data War In 2008|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2009/10/exclusive-how-democrats-won-the-data-war-in-2008/27647/|accessdate=10 November 2015|publisher=The Atlantic|date=October 5, 2009}}</ref>
==History== It was founded in 2006 by [[Harold M. Ickes]] with seed money from [[George Soros]]. It specializes in [[microtargeting]] for [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] political campaigns.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Knight|first1=Robert|title=Catalist, the left’s secret electoral weapon, outguns GOP|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/sep/19/knight-the-lefts-mighty-catalist/?page=all|accessdate=10 November 2015|publisher=Washington Times|date=September 19, 2014}}</ref> The company was founded as Data Warehouse, LLC.<ref name="CatalistBloomberg">{{cite web | title =Company Overview of Catalist LLC | url =https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=50279638 | website =Bloomberg | access-date =March 19, 2018 }}</ref>
Catalist's CEO is [[Laura Quinn]], an economic policy advisor in the U.S. Senate and former Deputy Chief of Staff for Vice President Al Gore.
In August 2016, Catalist analyzed records from 10 [[battleground states]] through June and found a major influx of new voters, majority-white, were responsible for the record-breaking turnout in the Republican primaries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/08/donald-trumps-great-white-hope-is-fading-fast.html|title=Donald Trump’s Great White Hope Is Fading Fast|access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/voter-influx-appears-missing-for-trump-1471912460|title=Voter Influx Appears Missing for Trump|last=Tau|first=ron|date=2016-08-23|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref> A collaboration between Catalist and [[SurveyMonkey]] showed that Sanders supporters voted less frequently and were less reliably Democratic than Clinton supporters.
During the 2008 U.S. presidential campaign, Catalist served as the principal repository of Democratic data, working with over 90 liberal groups including the [[Service Employees International Union]], the [[Democratic National Committee]], and the [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|2008 Barack Obama presidential campaign]].<ref name=atlantic/>
Catalist has engaged in [[data mining]] on behalf of clients such as [[Rock the Vote]] and [[EMILY's List]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Issenberg|first1=Sasha|title=For Sale: Detailed Voter Profiles|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/victory_lab/2012/01/the_co_op_and_the_data_trust_the_dnc_and_rnc_get_into_the_data_mining_business_.html|accessdate=10 November 2015|publisher=Slate|date=January 30, 2012}}</ref> Catalist receives funding from the [[Democracy Alliance]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Confessore|first1=Nicholas|title=Groups Mobilize to Aid Democrats in ’14 Data Arms Race|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/15/us/politics/groups-mobilize-to-aid-democrats.html|accessdate=11 November 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=November 14, 2013}}</ref>
In 2015, Catalist received $725,000 from the [[National Education Association]], a major teachers union.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2016/08/15/if-your-childs-school-is-failing-thank-union.html|title=If your child's school is failing, thank a union {{!}} Fox News|last=Berman|first=Richard|date=2016-08-15|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-24}}</ref>
The company as of 2018 claims that it has data on 240 million unique individuals in the United States, to be used by "progressive" organizations. Laura Quinn remained chief executive officer.<ref name="AboutCatalist">{{cite web | title =About Catalist | url =https://www.catalist.us/about/ | website =Catalist.us | access-date =March 19, 2018 }}</ref>

Photograph by Suzanne Roden.]] {{italic title}} '''''Daughters of Africa: An International Anthology of Words and Writings by Women of African Descent from the Ancient Egyptian to the Present''''' is a compilation of [[orature]] and literature by more than 200 women from Africa and the African diaspora, edited and introduced by [[Margaret Busby]],Tonya Bolden, [https://books.google.com/books?id=-lwEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT13&lpg=PT13&dq=%22daughters+of+africa%22+200+women&source=bl&ots=LVRNaM4dxY&sig=DSC5ZXzFB95-pCQ1FsM4KLyAq5o&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAmoVChMItJe82rygxwIVitYaCh3ziQ9d#v=onepage&q=%22daughters%20of%20africa%22%20200%20women&f=false "Book Review: Two Types of Revelation – ''Daughters of Africa''"], ''[[Black Enterprise]]'', March 1993, p. 12. who compared the process of assembling the volume to "trying to catch a flowing river in a calabash"."Introduction", ''Daughters of Africa'', p. xxix. First published in 1992,[http://kinnareads.com/2010/09/24/daughters-of-africa-edited-by-margaret-busby/ "Daughters of Africa edited by Margaret Busby"], Kinna Reads, 24 September 2010. in London by [[Jonathan Cape]] (having been commissioned by Candida Lacey,Candida Lacey, [http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/02690055.2017.1350365 "Daughters of Africa Twenty-five years later"], ''Wasafiri'', 32(4), November 2017, pp. 7–8. now publisher of [[Myriad Editions]]),Margaret Busby, [http://www.commonwealthwriters.org/granddaughters-of-africa-margaret-busby/ "Granddaughters of Africa"], [[Commonwealth Writers]], 19 March 2015. and in New York by [[Pantheon Books]], ''Daughters of Africa'' is regarded as a pioneering work,[http://www.african-writing.com/Sep/africanbritishprofile.htm#top Margaret Busby profile], African Writing in Britain.[http://www.bocaslitfest.com/awards/henry-swanzy-award/ "The 2015 Bocas Henry Swanzy Award Recipient: Margaret Busby, OBE"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702024441/http://www.bocaslitfest.com/awards/henry-swanzy-award/ |date=2 July 2015 }}, [[NGC Bocas Lit Fest]]. covering a variety of genres — including fiction, essays, poetry, drama, memoirs and children's writing — and more than 1000 pages in extent.[http://www.goodreads.com/book/show/2051521.Daughters_of_Africa "Daughters of Africa"], [[Goodreads]]. Arranged chronologically, it includes work translated from African languages as well as from Dutch, French, German, Portuguese, Russian and Spanish.[http://whatsonafrica.org/50-books-by-african-women-that-everyone-should-read/ "50 Books by African Women that Everyone Should Read"], What's_On Africa, Royal African Society, 30 June 2014.Meserette Kentake, [http://kentakepage.com/daughters-of-africa/ "Daughters of Africa"], Kentake Page, 17 December 2013. The anthology's title derives from an 1831 declaration by [[Maria W. Stewart]] (1803–1880), the first [[African-American]] woman to give public lectures, in which she said: "O, ye daughters of Africa, awake! awake! arise! no longer sleep nor slumber, but distinguish yourselves. Show forth to the world that ye are endowed with noble and exalted facutlies."Maria W. Stewart (ed. Marilyn Richardson), [https://books.google.com/books?id=noSOhOOsNuUC&pg=PA30&lpg=PA30&dq=maria+stewart+%22ye+daughters+of+africa%22&source=bl&ots=tuyBxyTqUE&sig=ZYGhcoSnPkaZTe-73tid8AVCvxQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAWoVChMIoa6CoLOtxwIVRrUaCh1igw9W#v=onepage&q=maria%20stewart%20%22ye%20daughters%20of%20africa%22&f=false "Religion And The Pure Principles of Morality, The Sure Foundation On Which We Must Build"], in ''America's First Black Woman Political Writer: Essays and Speeches''], [[Indiana University Press]], 1987, p. 30. ==Reception== ''Daughters of Africa'' was widely praised on publication. Reviewing it for Black British newspaper ''The Weekly Journal'', Evie Arup wrote: "''Daughters of Africa'' is a literary first. Never before has the work of women of African descent world-wide been gathered together in one volume. The breadth of this collection is startling.... This book should be required reading for any student of literature, and a standard reference book in school libraries, and, to paraphrase that well known slogan, 'every home should have one.'"Evie Arup, "Books: Daughters of Africa", ''The Weekly Journal'' (Issue 29), 12 November 1992, p. 15. The reviewer from ''[[The Independent]]'', however, observed: "This book may seem to be about literature but in the end it is as much a testament to language: its power to create attitudes as well as its potency as a means of expression."Patricia Lee, [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/books/book-review-canon-to-the-right-of-them-canon-to-the-left-daughters-of-africa-ed-margaret-busby-1563049.html "BOOK REVIEW / Canon to the right of them, canon to the left..."], ''The Independent'', 12 December 1992. According to ''[[Library Journal]]'', the anthology is "an invaluable text for courses on women writers and writers of African descent",[http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/daughters-of-africa-margaret-busby/1002938755#productInfoTabs "Daughters of Africa: An International Anthology of Words and Writings by Women of African Descent and from the Ancient Egyptian to the Present"], Barnes & Noble. and Keneth Kinnamon in ''[[Callaloo (journal)|Callaloo]]'' saw it as "impressive", noting: "Brief headnotes and long bibliographies enhance the value of this important volume."Keneth Kinnamon, "Anthologies of African-American Literature from 1845 to 1994", in ''Callaloo'', Vol. 20, No. 2 (Spring, 1997), p. 468. [[Lorna Sage]] in the ''Independent on Sunday'' concluded that "''Daughters of Africa'' has a paradoxical universality",Lorna Sage, "Deep roots in an impossible homeland", The Sunday Review, ''Independent on Sunday'', 3 January 1993, p. 21. while ''[[The Washington Post Book World]]'' called it: "A magnificent starting place for any reader interested in becoming part of the collective enterprise of discovering and uncovering the silent, forgotten, and underrated voices of black women."[https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/entertainment/books/1994/02/06/new-in-paperback/438e9308-0e92-44ef-a403-3fde2d87806a/ "New in Paperback"], ''The Washington Post'', 6 February 1994.Shereen Ali, [http://m.guardian.co.tt/lifestyle/2015-04-29/sharing-our-voices "Sharing Our Voices"], ''[[Trinidad and Tobago Guardian]]'', 29 April 2015. The reviewer for ''[[Black Enterprise]]'' wrote: "It is a landmark anthology.... Busby's first-of-a-kind anthology is a poignant reminder of how vast and varied the body of black women's writing is." It has also been described as "groundbreaking",[https://www.theguardian.com/profile/margaret-busby Margaret Busby profile], ''[[The Guardian]]''. as "one of the most significant assemblages of writers across the diaspora"Carol Boyce Davies, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7QEjPVyd9YMC&pg=PA384&lpg=PA384&dq=%22Daughters+of+Africa%22+%22margaret+busby%22&source=bl&ots=uqtNXKoCPA&sig=5BNdSUI3ahIcdmpA-st1pgEJ5mk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CJIBEOgBMBhqFQoTCJ_a55Cmn8cCFUTaGgod8QwMWQ#v=onepage&q=%22Daughters%20of%20Africa%22%20%22margaret%20busby%22&f=false "Women and Literature in the African Diaspora"], in Melvin Ember, Carol R. Ember, Ian Skoggard (eds), ''Encyclopedia of Diasporas: Immigrant and Refugee Cultures Around the World, Volume 1'', Springer Science and Business Media Inc., 2005, p. 384. and as "the ultimate reference guide to the writing of 'daughters of Africa'".Sharmilla Beezmohun, [http://www.wasafiri.org/pages/content/index.asp?PageID=307 "Twenty-Five most influential books"], ''[[Wasafiri]]'', 2009. It was included in ''Sacred Fire: "QBR" 100 Essential Black Books'',Max Rodriguez, [https://books.google.com/books/about/Sacred_Fire.html?id=FDxEAAAAMAAJ ''Sacred Fire: "QBR" 100 Essential Black Books''], University of Michigan, 1999. which said:
"''Daughters of Africa'' is a monumental achievement because it is the most comprehensive international anthology of oral and written literature by women of African descent ever attempted. (...) The success of the collection is that it clearly illustrates why all women of African descent are connected by showing how closely related are the obstacles, the chasms of cultural indifference, and the disheartening racial and sexual dilemmas they faced. In so doing, the collection captures the range of their singular and combined accomplishments. ''Daughters of Africa''′s accomplishment lies in its glorious portrayal of the richness and magnitude of the spiritual well from which we've all drawn inspiration and to where we've all gone for sustenance, and as such, it is a stunning literary masterpiece."
The anthology was on the [[Royal African Society]]'s list of "50 Books By African Women That Everyone Should Read",[http://whatsonafrica.org/50-books-by-african-women-that-everyone-should-read/# "50 Books by African Women That Everyone Should Read"], What's On Africa, RAS, 30 June 2014. was named by ''Ms Afropolitan'' as one of "7 non-fiction books African feminists should read",[http://www.msafropolitan.com/2015/09/non-fiction-books-for-african-feminists.html "7 non-fiction books African feminists should read"], ''Ms Afropolitan'', 27 September 2015. features regularly on many required-reading lists,Sandra E. Gibbs, [http://www.ncte.org/library/NCTEFiles/Involved/Action/AARI/Young_Adults_Adults.pdf "National African American Read-In"], Supplemental List for Young Adults and Adults, Recommended by Black Caucus Members.[[Nana Darkoa Sekyiamah]], [http://thisisafrica.me/lifestyle/feminist-books-inspired-us-part-1/ "The feminist books that inspired us – Part 1"], This Is Africa, 24 February 2015.[http://www.blackpastblog.org/2012/08/thinking-of-travel-armchair-and.html "Thinking of Travel: Armchair and Otherwise"], BlackPast.org, 2 August 2012.Yinka Sunmonu, [http://www.voice-online.co.uk/article/bookshelf-cultural-collection "Bookshelf: A Cultural Collection"], ''[[The Voice (newspaper)|The Voice]]'', 26 December 2015.[https://canonofonesown.com/2016/03/18/womens-classic-literature-event-questionnaire/ "Women’s Classic Literature Event Questionnaire"], A Canon Of One's Own, 18 March 2016. and in the words of Kinna Likimani: "It remains the ultimate guide to women writers of African descent." In November 2017 ''[[Wasafiri]]'' magazine included a special feature marking the 25th anniversary of the first publication of ''Daughters of Africa'',[https://www.wasafiri.org/product/wasafiri-issue-92/ "Daughters of Africa Anniversary"], ''Wasafiri'', Issue 92: Winter 2017. including an interview with the editor by [[Ellah Wakatama Allfrey]],Ellah Wakatama Allfrey (2017), [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/02690055.2017.1350364?journalCode=rwas20 "An Interview with Margaret Busby"], ''Wasafiri'', 32:4, pp. 2–6, DOI: 10.1080/02690055.2017.1350364. an article by Candida LaceyCandida Lacey, [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/02690055.2017.1350365 "Daughters of Africa – Twenty-five years later"], ''Wasafiri'', 32(4), pp. 7–8. and contributions from [[Edwige-Renee Dro]], [[Angela Barry]], [[Goretti Kyomuhendo]], [[Nadifa Mohamed]], [[Phillippa Yaa de Villiers]] and [[Ayobami Adebayo]] about the influence of the anthology on them.Edwige-Renée Dro, Angela Barry, Goretti Kyomuhendo, Nadifa Mohamed, Phillippa Yaa de Villiers & Ayobami Adebayo, [https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/02690055.2017.1350367 "Encounters with Daughters of Africa from around the world"], ''Wasafiri'', 32(4), pp. 11–12. In December 2017, it was announced that a companion volume, to be called ''New Daughters of Africa'', had been commissioned from Margaret Busby by [[Myriad Editions]].Natasha Onwuemezi, [https://www.thebookseller.com/news/myriad-commissions-new-anthology-about-african-women-writers-689486 "Busby to compile anthology of African women writers"], ''The Bookseller'', 15 December 2017.[https://brittlepaper.com/2018/01/anthology-edited-margaret-busby-collects-writing-200-african-women-generations/ "Margaret Busby-Edited Anthology to Feature 200 Female Writers Including Adichie, Aminatta Forna, Bernadine Evaristo, Imbolo Mbue, Warsan Shire, Zadie Smith"], ''Brittle Paper'', 10 January 2018.[http://myriadeditions.com/books/new-daughters-of-africa/ ''New Daughters of Africa'' page] at Myriad. ==Contributors== More than 200 women are featured in ''Daughters of Africa'', including: {{div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[Opal Palmer Adisa]] * [[Abena Adomako]] * [[Ama Ata Aidoo]] * [[Grace Akello]] * [[Zaynab Alkali]] * [[Ifi Amadiume]] * [[Maya Angelou]] * [[Red Jordan Arobateau]]Red Jordan Arobateau, [https://books.google.com/books?id=npauBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA249&lpg=PA249&dq=%22Daughters+of+Africa%22+%22margaret+busby%22&source=bl&ots=4PZoGxcaHC&sig=fxnwp0VEkqo5NvrpNhevBXYgZVo&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CIcBEOgBMBVqFQoTCJ_a55Cmn8cCFUTaGgod8QwMWQ#v=onepage&q=%22Daughters%20of%20Africa%22%20%22margaret%20busby%22&f=false ''The Rich/The Poor In Spirit''] - New Edition, 2013, p. 249. * Iola Ashundie * [[Mariama Bâ]] * [[Baba of Karo|Baba]] * [[Toni Cade Bambara]] * [[Valerie Belgrave]] * [[Gwendolyn B. '''Esperantology''', or '''Esperanto studies''', is a special [[Esperanto]] linguistics whose subjects are word construction, word assembly, word introduction and transcription of [[umbrella term]]s and proper names. Esperantology principles of word construction are exemplary of the principles of necessity and sufficiency which postulate a balance between conciseness and clarity of the word. Regarding word roots, esperantology sets these principles:
* The principle of internationality * The principle of analogy with other language elements * The principle of the vocabulary being economical * The principle of euphony
As it is possible to see, all these principles are not always in accordance among themselves; for example the principle of internationality asks for the word ''internacionala'' while the analogy and the dictionary being economical as for the word ''internacia''. In the language, the second and third rule are stronger than the first one.
Besides, the absolute validity of the above-mentioned principles also obstructs the language use, which can sanction not that correct forms and can clarify forms not clear enough.
==Literature== * Wüster: Esperantologiaj principoj (E-Germana Vortaro). Neergard: Fremdvortoj en E. Tie oni trovas ankaŭ bibliografian liston. KALOCSAY. * Welger: Germanlingva studo pri la starigo, prioritatigo kaj interagado de planlingvaj kvalitokriterioj en la verkaro de Zamenhof
==See also== * [[Interlinguistics]] * [[Esperantic Studies Foundation]]

{{italic title}} [[File:ExilesOnAsperus.jpg|thumb|First edition, cover art by Colin Hay]]
'''''Exiles on Asperus''''' ({{ISBN|0-340-24046-6}}) is a collection of [[science fiction]] short stories by [[John Wyndham]], writing as John Benyon, published in 1979 after his death by [[Coronet Books]].
The collection contains:
*Exiles on Asperus (1933) *No Place Like Earth (1951) *The Venus Adventure (1932)
Exiles tells the story of a human crew who are transporting a group of Martian dissidents to a penal colony only for the captives to revolt leading to the crew, prisoners, and the survivors of a previous crash becoming embroiled in a battle for survival against the indigenous life form of the planet Asperus.
No Place Like Earth sees a survivor of the Earth's destruction facing a slow, quiet life on Mars or becoming part of the efforts to keep humanity alive on Venus, and the repercussions of his decision.
The Venus Adventure tells of an early flight to Venus and the surprising world the crew of the Fyra discover. Not only are there intelligent indigenous lifeforms, and a breathable atmosphere, there are also fellow humans.
{{John Wyndham}}

[[Image:Francois geny1.jpg|right|thumb|150px|François Gény, the main jusphilosopher of the ''free scientific research'']] The '''free scientific research''' is a ''[[Philosophy of law|jusphilosophical]] school'' precursor of the [[jurisprudence of values]],<ref name="IPEUT">{{cite web|url=http://www.ipeut.com/droit/loi-generale/387/definition-de-la-libre-recherc33888.php|title=Définition de la libre recherche scientifique|publisher=Ipeut|accessdate=2 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="ARTDIR">{{cite web|url=http://www.centrorisorse.org/classical-schools-of-interpretation.html|title=Classical Schools of Interpretation|publisher=Centrorisore.org Article Directory|author=Gett, Ivelisse|accessdate=2 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="ARCOS">{{cite web|url=http://www.arcos.org.br/livros/hermeneutica-juridica/capitulo-iii-o-positivismo-normativista/3-a-jurisprudencia-dos-conceitos/|title=A Jurisprudência dos Conceitos|author=Costa, Alexandre Araújo|publisher=Arcos|accessdate=17 December 2011}}</ref><ref name="FDV">{{cite web|url=http://www.fdv.br/publicacoes/periodicos/revistadepoimentos/n7/6.pdf|title=A importância da Jurisprudência dos Conceitos para a Metodologia Jurídica|author=Pepino, Elsa Maria Lopes Ferreira; Graviorno, Gracimeri, Vieira Soeiro de Castro; Filgueira, Sofia Varejão|publisher=Revista Depoimentos, da Faculdade de Direito de Vitória|accessdate=17 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119225127/http://www.fdv.br/publicacoes/periodicos/revistadepoimentos/n7/6.pdf|archivedate=19 January 2012|df=}}</ref> which defends basically that, in order to discover the origins of law's [[principle]]s and ''rules'', the interpreter's studies may have support on various "sciences" such as [[sociology]], [[economics]], [[linguistics]], [[philosophy]] and [[theology]], that previous law teachers had not used before.
Its main name is [[François Gény]] and there are others like ''Stamler''<ref name="REDS">{{cite web|url=http://www.reds.msh-paris.fr/publications/collvir/crj-html/partie1-1-2.htm|title=Critique de la Raison Juridique|author=Arnaud, André-Jean|publisher=Réseau Européenne Droit et Societé|accessdate=2 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928111001/http://www.reds.msh-paris.fr/publications/collvir/crj-html/partie1-1-2.htm|archivedate=28 September 2011|df=}}</ref><ref name="MASTSCI">{{cite web|url=http://master.sciences-po.fr/droit/sites/master.sciences-po.fr.droit/files/users/annesolenne.deroux/L%C3%A9on%20DUGUIT%20et%20Fran%C3%A7ois%20GENY%20controverse%20sur%20la%20r%C3%A9novation%20de%20la%20science%20juridique.pdf|title=Léon Duguit et François Gény, Controverse sur la rénovation de la science juridique|author=Chazal, Jean Pascal|publisher=Portail des Masters de Sciences|accessdate=2 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="ARTNETSAB">{{cite web|url=http://artigos.netsaber.com.br/resumo_artigo_8463/artigo_sobre_direitos_e_deveres_do_preso|title=Direitos e Deveres do Preso|author=Dias, Ailton Henrique|publisher=Netsaber Artigos|accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref> and [[Eugen Ehrlich]].<ref name="OST">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7EkWRS-8MbEC&pg=PA434&lpg=PA434&dq=ehrlich+%22libre+recherche+scientifique%22&source=bl&ots=fmqMzoIR76&sig=RnBPD5gIB88_FLOYxzplnsY0PMQ&hl=pt-BR&sa=X&ei=h2vKT9_dGIam8QT9zMTxDg&ved=0CEkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=ehrlich%20%22libre%20recherche%20scientifique%22&f=false|last=Ost|first=François|author2=Kerchove, Michel van de|title=De la Pyramide au Reseau, pour une Théorie Dialectique du Droit|place=Bruxelles|publisher=Facultés Universitaires Saint Louis|year=2002|page=434}}</ref><ref name="UCP">{{cite web|url=http://pt.scribd.com/doc/51672833/Hermeneutica-Juridica-Sist-Interpretativos-Livre-Pesquisa-Cientifica-trab|title=Hermenêutica Jurídica - Sistemas Interpretativos - Livre Pesquisa Científica|author=Leite, Beatriz; Scheunemann, Fabriciane, Prestes, Maria Lygia; Dillmann, Roberta; Schneider, Sandra Bergmann|date=October 2008|publisher=Scribd|accessdate=24 April 2012}}</ref>
This school is also referred as the '''French school''' of interpretation<ref name="WEBART">{{cite web|url=http://www.webartigos.com/artigos/escolas-de-livre-interpretacao/15592/|title=Escolas de livre investigação acerca do Direito|author=Carneiro, Carla Michele|publisher=Web Artigos|accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref> and [[Inheritance (computer science)|inherits]] aspects from [[Greek philosophy]].<ref name="MEDIT">{{cite web|url=http://www.mediterranee-antique.info/Grece/Croiset/Civil_Grece/CGA_11.htm|title=La Civilisation de la Grèce Antique|publisher=Histoire Antique|accessdate=16 April 2012}}</ref>
== Concepts == The ''free scientific'' intended to solve the contradictions of the [[exegesis]] school and improve the traditional [[Legal positivism|juspositivism]]. One of its goals was to complete the "voids" of legal order<ref>See also [[A Theory of Legal Order]]</ref> fulfilling them with scientific elements, so denying law as the unique source of that order.<ref name="TRADULEX">{{cite web|url=http://www.tradulex.org/Actes2000/kasirer.pdf|title=François Gény's "Libre Recherche Scientifique" as a Guide to Legal Translation|author=Kasirer, Nicholas|publisher=Tradulex.org|accessdate=2 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="CONTJUR">{{cite web|url=http://www.conteudojuridico.com.br/monografia-tcc-tese,a-hermeneutica-na-aplicacao-dos-principios-juridicos,23352.html|title=A Hermenêutica na Aplicação dos Princípios Jurídicos|author=Mendonça, Aline Cala|date=12 March 2009|publisher=Conteúdo Jurídico|accessdate=21 April 2012}}</ref>
This thinking paradigm emphasizes the use of [[Equity (law)|equity]] as source of the law.<ref name="STUD">{{cite web|url=http://www.studility.com/?q=node/16|title=La réalisation du droit|publisher=Studility|accessdate=2 June 2012}}</ref><ref name="JUSNAV2">{{cite web|url=http://jus.com.br/revista/texto/9032/estudos-sobre-interpretacao-constitucional|title=Estudos sobre Interpretação Constitucional|author=Chamone, Marcelo Azevedo|date=September 2006|publisher=Jus Navigandi|accessdate=27 April 2012}}</ref>
== Free scientific research and ''nature of things'' == The free scientific school has elements which have come from the philosophical school called the ''[[Nature (philosophy)|nature of things]]''.<ref name="HASSO">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-6cfY3iaYnsC&pg=PA321&lpg=PA321|last=Hasso|first=Hofmann|title=A Treatise of Legal Philosophy and General Jurisprudence - From Jhering to Hadbruch|publisher=Springer|year=2009|isbn=978-90-481-2963-8|page=321}}</ref><ref name="ISCSP">{{cite web|url=http://www.iscsp.utl.pt/~cepp/autores/franceses/geny.htm|title=Gény, François|publisher=Insituto Superior de Ciências Sociais e Políticas da Universidade Técnica de Lisboa|accessdate=21 April 2012}}</ref>
== Confusion == The free scientific school may not be identified to the ''[[natural law]]'', they are different concepts.<ref name="JUSCOM">{{cite web|url=http://jus.com.br/revista/texto/6751/o-processo-do-conhecimento-humano-e-as-correntes-do-pensamento-juridico|title=O Processo do Conhecimento Humano e as Correntes do Pensamento Jurídico|author=Borges, José Ademir Campos|date=June 2004|publisher=Jus Navigandi|accessdate=26 April 2012}}</ref> There can also be confusion between free scientific with ''free law''.<ref>This school denies application of imposed law when unfair in the concrete case</ref> These two schools are not identical one to the other.<ref name="BUSCAUFSC">{{cite web|url=http://www.buscalegis.ufsc.br/revistas/files/anexos/15235-15236-1-PB.htm|title=O Direito Alternativo e a Escola do Direito Livre|author=Liberato, Gustavo Tavares Cavalcanrti|publisher=Buscalegis|accessdate=25 April 2012}}</ref>
== Position of the school between other thinking paradigms == As said above, this school is a start in facing the challenges of adjusting juspositivism to a value-oriented paradigm.
== Bibliography == * {{cite book|last=Motte|first=Olivier J.|pages=236|chapter=Gény, François |editor=Michael Stolleis (ed.) |title= Juristen: ein biographisches Lexikon; von der Antike bis zum 20. Jahrhundert |edition=2nd|year=2001|publisher=Beck|location=München|language=German|isbn=3406459579}}
